@Angle Daily Not exactly correct.
The proverb “It takes a village to raise a child” is an old Nigerian saying.
It is better translated as “It takes a COMMUNITY to raise a child.”

The meaning is more akin to the philosophy that the whole community is responsible for children’s good or bad development.

Because, growing up, children get influenced by their whole community.
Their mothers,fathers,friends,teachers,religious authorities and so on and so forth. Everyone in the child’s life takes a part in shaping who they become.

I’ve never seen anyone take this saying as a carte blanche to evade their parental responsibilities.

We can clearly see, based on the replies here, that it’s only the original poster who didn’t get that quote’s actual meaning. Because he (or she) ironically described exactly what the quote was about, whilst try to denounce it.
@Angle Daily I can get down with the old definition.

When most people say 'it takes a village' now, they mean they want less responsibility.  In the past though it meant more responsibility.  If there were kids in the street, you watched out for them, if kids were at your house, you fed them. If there are kids acting like fools, you correct them.
Mom, dad AND teacher AND pastor........ so, in other words, A VILLAGE!

The parents, teachers and pastor are the "village". The saying "it takes a village" doesn't mean that your whole neighborhood is gonna be involved in your child's upbringing, the village to refers to the parents, teachers, pastors, next door neighbor (which in many african cultures they're considered family) aunts, uncles, etc.

Sex and reproduction are the greatest drives humans have to form pair bonds and create families, and this de-links sex from reproduction, and ultimately even from relationships in general.

This mass immigration they promote then makes it even more difficult for the native population to start families and raise children because of the downward pressure on the value of labor that waves of mass immigration creates.

It's also clear that declining birth rates are very easy to rectify. Germany solved their demographic crisis in the 1930s merely by promoting mortgage loans with great terms for people to get married, and tax breaks for having children. Hungary has similarly fixed their demographic crisis, just during the time that Orban has been in office.
